We study public policies with a dedicated, objective, and an unbiased approach. We strive to initiate policy changes by publishing our research and by framing policy debates and discussions on various subjects. Our research areas include Governance, Education, Health, Law, Livelihood, Strategy & Security and Urban Reforms. We have carried out research projects and worked on policy papers for government bodies, private institutions, and academia; many of which have had a profound impact at the governance level. CPPR has a good research team comprising of professionals from different fields of expertise and resource persons from across the world. Research internship is another key activity of CPPR. CPPR produces working papers in various fields. Innovative policy solutions and ideas that are in sync with global technological revolutions and entrepreneurship are the key components of our policy research.

detailsOfAchievement: Environmental Efficiency and Carrying Capacity(EE&CC) are two strong indicators of sustainable development contributing to global sustainability and smart cities with smart resource regions at local level. We have launched a website by www.centreforenvironmentalefficiency.org in which video clippings, pictures, write ups etc are included to give awareness of the innovative and robust concepts which take environment and development hand-in-hand We are giving presentations at various forums like Institution of Engineers, Institution of Town Planners, Indian Institute of architects etc. This is to create awareness of this concept contributing to global to local prosperity. We have published a book by name Environmental Efficiency and Carrying Capacity Indicators. We have opened a facebook page for CEE in which Environmental Efficiency and Carrying Capacity concepts are explained in simple words. We have associated with conducting seminars and have published research papers. We have associated with the Greater Cochin Development Authority in formulating sustainable projects for Greater Kochi Metropolitan Area. Kochi Hygeia Valley, Cycle Tracks, logistic centre based on EE Approach etc are only some of them. Centre for Environmental Efficiency volunteered to take up this innovative idea for taking part in the smart city challenge of Government of India

detailsOfAchievement: CENTRE FOR GERONTOLOGICAL STUDIES Major Activities and Achievemets I. Origin The Centre for Gerontological Studies (CGS), Thiruvananthapuram was established in 1983 by forward looking social scientists from universities in 5 South Indian States as an international centre for inter-disciplinary studies and research on aging. The major objectives of the Centre are to (a) organize, promote and execute programmes of study and research on aging and generate knowledge that is socially relevant, (b) examine government policies, programmes and legislations that have gerontological bearing and prepare reports that may be useful for policy makers and programme planners, (c) organize and conduct seminars, workshops, symposia and study groups on major issues of population aging, II. Activities 1. Conferences & Seminars organised a). First International Seminar on Population Aging in India. 1985 b). International Congress on Aging, 1996 c). First International Colloquium on the Oldest Old (80+) February, 2009 d) First International Workshop on Human Rights of Older Persons in the Asia Pacific Region with Focus on Health and Wellbeing June 2012. e) International Conference on Elder Dignity and Abuse 2014 f). National Seminar on Empowerment of Women with Focus on Old Women - 1998 g). First National Seminar on Widowhood in India with focus on Elderly Widows 2002 h). First National Seminar on Abuse of the Elderly in India. 2004 j). First National Convention on Older Women with focus on health and well being 2010 k). Several State and Local Level Seminars 2. Major Studies conducted a) International (1) Sandoz Foundation for Gerontological Research. â€œStudy on Healthy Aging and Independence in Later Life.â€ (2) International Social Security Association, Geneva. â€œStudy on Social Security System in the Asia Pacific Regionâ€ (3) WHO, Kobe, Japan â€œMethodological Issues in Health Expectancy Researchâ€ b) National â€œStudy of the Old-Old and Oldest Oldâ€ â€œStudy on Abuse of the Elderlyâ€. â€œStudy on Problems and Needs of Widowsâ€ Study on â€œInter-generational Integration â€œStudy on Sustainability of Self Employment Programmes for the Unemployed in Keralaâ€. â€œStudy on Old Age Homes in Keralaâ€. â€œStudy on Health Care System, Health Seeking Behaviour and Health Outcomesâ€ 3. Training Programme National Institute of Social Defence, New Delhi, â€œCertificate Course in Basic Issues in Geriatric Care for Supervisors of Old Age Homesâ€. February-March 2007 Four training programmes for the Govt. of Kerala for Supervisors of Old Age Homes 2015. 4. Kerala State Policy on Older Persons, 2006 This was prepared by CGS 5. Helpline & Counseling The Centre has a Helpline and Counselling Bureau. 6. Current Ongoing Programme Age Friendly Grama Panchayat Programme is being run very successfully with Government support in 6 Grama Panchayats in Kerala as a unique innovative project of CGS with emphasis on bottom-up planning. III. Achievements - National Recognition For outstanding contribution to aging, Government of India SJ&E Ministry conferred on CGS its highest award - The Vayoshreshtha Samman 2009. For significant contribution for senior citizens, CGS Chairman, Dr. P.K.B. Nayar, received the Vayoshreshtha Samman - Life-Time Achievement Award 2014 from Government of India SJ&E Ministry.

detailsOfAchievement: In the last three years CISSA has organized various national seminars and workshops in the chosen focal areas and initiated massive public movements in favour of traditional food & health practices and clean technologies. Ayurveda and public health has a prominent place in CISSAâ€™s activities. Some of the major activities in these areas are Annam Good Food Movement was launched in India in 2008 as a joint initiative of the CISSA, Navdanya, India and the Slow Food Movement (Italy). It is an effort to popularize the concepts of food and health in our traditional health systems, to make the people aware of the linkage between good food, local agro-biodiversity and health, fight for food security and food sovereignty in the era of globalisalion where corporates are in the pursuit to monopolize food and agriculture. This has become a landmark event in India in terms of participation of government departments, public and private organizations, public support, and follow-up activities envisaged. When the Kerala state was reeling under Chikungunya epidemic,CISSA organized workshop on Ayurvedic approach towards its management. Physicians from Chikungunya affected areas and renowned academicians participated. Role of Ayurveda in public health activities aimed at controlling mosquito born epidemics were also discussed. This workshop helped the Ayurvedic community to confidently proclaim that even simple Ayurvedic techniques are effective in treating Chikungunya especially the arthritis associated with it, when public health authorities were solely depending on Allopathic system of medicine. The workshop on diagnostic imaging and ECG provided an excellent opportunity to have insight on use of various diagnostic imaging techniques and ECG in common conditions encountered in day today practices. The national seminar on Contribution of Indian Philosophical system to Ayurveda was a scholarly exercised to view the philosophical theories in the light of modern scientific advancements Currently working on a project proposal based on Geriatric Care using Ayurvedic intervention.

detailsOfAchievement: KARUNYAVARSHAM STARTED ON 10TH APRIL, 2011 BY SERVING MEALS TO 100 PATIENTS IN GOVT MEDICAL COLLEGE HOSPITAL, ERNAKULAM, KALAMASSERY AND SUBSEQUENTLY REGISTERED WITH THE SUB REGISTRAR, THRIKKAKA DURING DECEMBER 2013. NOW WE HAVE BEEN SERVING FOOD TO MORE THAN 300 PATIENTS AND THEIR BYSTANDERS IN THE SAME HOSPIT FROM MONDAY TO SATURDAY AND TWO MEALS ON SUNDAYS. WE ARE PLANNING TO SERVE THREE MEALS EVERY DAY WITH NUTRITIOUS FOOD TO WOMEN AND CHILDREN. WE ARE ALSO PROVING AMBULANCE, LAB TEST CHARGES, MEDICINE CHARGES TO THE POOREST OF THE POOR PEOPLE. WE ARE ALSO RUNNING A FAMILY CONSELLING CENTRE, AT PALARIVATTOM, ERNAKULAM. IT IS MEANT FOR FAMILY, CHILDREN, INDIVIDUALS ETC. WE HAVE SUPPLIED FOOD PACKETS TO THE FAMILIES WHERE THEIR BREAD WINNER IS BED RIDDEN. we ARE ALSO RUNNING A PALLIATIVE HOME CARE SERVICE IT HELPS THE PATIENTS FOR THEIR NURSING NEEDS. WE ARE ALSO PROVING SUPPORTING EQUIPMENTS SUCH AS AIR BED, WHEEL CHAIR ETC TO THE BED RIDDEN PATIENTS.

address: Kathakali School Society Centre for the Performing Arts and Culture Cheruthuruthy Thrissur-679531 Kerala
title: Kathakali School
detailsOfAchievement: Kathakali School, a centre for performing arts and culture is situated in Cheruthuruthy, Kerala, India since 1990. It is the unified effort of a group of the alumni of Kerala Kalamandalam led by Kalamandalam Gopalakrishnan. The Kathakali School staff are highly qualified and eminent performers. We are primarily a teaching institution and the school concentrates on the classical performing arts of Kerala, Kathakali, Mohiniyattam and Theyyam along with several folk and martial arts forms like Kalaripayattu. Kathakali School has performed in almost every continents. In India the school has conducted a number of programmes and workshops for Government and Private Organizations at all major Indian cities. The main workshops were conducted at Bangalore, Mumbai and Hyderabad at various times for CCRT, Govt of India. The Kendra Sangeetha Nataka Academy has also conducted workshops with the school. Kathakali School usually participates in partnership with Kerala Tourism at several places in India. We are also participants in the Govt. of India Cultural Exchange programmes with schools abroad. The south and north zone cultural centres frequently invite Kathakali School for workshops and performances. We feel we have shared in the efforts to preserve and propagate the ancient art forms that define Kerala.

detailsOfAchievement: Kerala Educational Development and Employment Society (KEDES) established in 1983 aims to reduce poverty by investing in the development of human capital with the aim of building skills and making knowledge available to all members of civil society for longterm sustainable development.KEDES encourages, and assists villagers to set up rural and small industries under the Micro & Small Industries Programme of the Govt. of India so as to give relief to the poor by providing full-time or part-time employment after imparting necessary training and ensure fair and reasonable wages. The emphais of KEDES is in organising vocationa, skill based training, ICT controlled education/online education that are employment oriented apart from providing general awareness for inclusive growth. In this respect CAPART, of the Ministry of Rural Development, Govt. of India had assessed the functioning of KEDES in 2008 and published its success stories. This is the first in Kerala and 52nd in the country since the inception of CAPART in 1986.

detailsOfAchievement: The Kerala Statistical Institute (KSI) was established in December 1977 as a professional, non-commercial organization by a group of experts in statistics, economics, management and education. Since its inception, the Institute has carried out projects funded or supported by Government of India, Government of Kerala, renowned institutions like the Centre for Development Studies (CDS) and international agencies. KSI has proven capabilities and is fully geared to undertake major project assignments in an integrated basis from planning to analysis to, report writing as per pre-assigned time frame with an eye on qualitative aspects. The Institute has a live panel of experienced field supervisors and well trained investigators (male / female) located in all districts of the State and in neighbouring States. The panel consists of graduates / post-graduates. Most of the projects handled by KSI involved collection of data from a large number of households and non-household establishments, their processing and analysis. KSI has developed professional expertise geared to attend to large scale data processing and analysis needs of governmental and non-governmental organisations. In the field of data base management the Institute has developed competence to develop built-in data entry programmes as a prelude to the process of data entry and take up validation of data to ensure completeness and consistency. The following are some of the major achievements of KSI. â€¢ Need Assessment Study of Older Population in Kerala. Funded by United Nations Fund for Population Activities (UNFPA) through the Department of Health Services. Government of Kerala 2005. â€¢ Household Savings, Investments and Indebtedness in Kerala. Funded by Science, Technology and Environment Department, Government of Kerala 2003-04. â€¢ Endline Survey of ICDS III in Kerala funded by World Bank through Government of India, 2006. â€¢ Census of Computer / IT training institutions in Kerala funded by Kerala State Information Technology Mission, Government of Kerala, 2007. â€¢ Construction of a Forecasting Model for Coconut Oil Prices in India funded by Coconut Development Board, Government of India, 2007. â€¢ Field Survey on Migration in Kerala (international and internal including return migration, replacement migration) for the year 1998, 2000, 2001, 2003, 2007, 2008 and 2009. Funded by Centre for Development Studies. â€¢ Conversion of Paddy Land in Kerala, 1992- 1994 Funded by STED. â€¢ A unique study on the quality of living in 10 localities in Kerala was carried out in 1979-82. This was repeated at approximate intervals of 5 years in the same localities. â€¢ Impact of surplus land allotment in Kerala,1993- 94 Funded by Ministry of Rural Areas and Employment, Government of India. â€¢ Gender Inequality in Intra - Household Consumption Expenditure - Development of Methodology. Funded by Central Statistical Organisation 2004. â€¢ Morbidity in Kerala â€“Incidence, Prevalence and Associates. Funded by Centre for Development Studies 2003. â€¢ Household Cost of School Education in Kerala. Funded by Centre for Development Studies 2003. â€¢ Concurrent evaluation of various programmes like Integrated Rural Development Programmes, Indira Awaas Yojana, Million Wells Scheme (Kerala, Lakshadweep), Rural Development programmes (Tamil Nadu) and Impact Assessment of Watershed Development project (Karnataka). Funded by Ministry of Rural Areas and Employment, Government of India.
